Event Title: Hillside Mini-Farm Fall Tree Climbing Day
Location: the farm with other garden and family activities, music, food, and FUN
Description: We are so excited to CLIMB TREES!  Brought to us by Riverside Outfitters, this free community event will combine our love of caring for trees with fun and adventure!Youth ages 6 and up are invited to do a vertical climb and/or limb walk. All gear will be provided by Riverside Outfitters. Youth under 18 years old will require a parent/guardian to sign a waiver (available here or on site the day of the event).Come and enjoy a day at the farm with other garden and family activities, music, food, and FUN!Farm activity with our Green TeamGiant bubble and stone mandala activity with Open Source EducationTree climbing and field games with Riverside OutfittersGrill out and musicClick here to learn more about tree climbing with Riverside Outfitters!Richmond is going to be planting and taking care of many trees over the next decade as we move to improve our tree canopy, especially in heat-impacted, Black and Brown Communities. Trees ARE the answer, in many ways. And their world has often been foreign to many in our communities. Our friends at Riverside Outfitters see the adventure, fun and potential skill set that learning to “climb like the pros” can bring. If you’ve ever seen a tree person Up There, just being and seeing the world, you’ll know what we’re talking about. SO - Let’s go!! There are great trees at the Hillside Mini-Farm, and friends eager to teach young folks that climbing them IS A BLAST!

Chuck Winchell grew up in the Mill Hill area of Bridgeport in the 60’s. He has been involved with Groundwork Bridgeport since its inception in 1998, having served as a Board member and Chair. Chuck retired from the United Illuminating Company and enjoyed a second career with the State of Connecticut’s Department of Energy and Environmental Protection. In 1981 he hiked 1,000 miles of the Appalachian Trail and has been chipping away at the remaining 1,100 ever since. Besides hiking, Chuck’s other interests include swimming, biking, and weekly pinochle games.Chris Allen, a retired Agriscience teacher from Trumbull High School, specialized in the plant science portion of the program. He holds a degree in plant science from Penn State and has expertise in greenhouse production, hydroponics, and plant tissue culture. An avid hiker, Chris has explored nearly all local hiking trails, the Connecticut Appalachian Trail, and several peaks in New Hampshire's White Mountains.

Description: The Nature Nights Free Film Series continues with Ice Age, followed by Voice of the Glaciers, directed by Sindre Kolbjørnsgard. Voice of the Glaciers takes place in the summer of 2019, when four young adventurers embark on a dangerous scientific expedition into the Arctic, with the intent of documenting the true story of the effects of the changing climate. Through Eric’s scientific degree in glaciology, and Kris' crucial knowledge of navigating the local terrain, working as an Arctic guide, the team approach the endeavor with open minds, seeking evidence, to determine fact from hysteria, about the rate of glacial melting.

Event Title: Walking Club: Hike the Pequonnock River Trail
Location: rail-trail portion of the Pequonnock River Trail
Description:
Join our Walking Club on a hike every first Saturday of each month! Led by volunteers Chuck and Chris (see more below), we will do easier hikes to come together and enjoy CT’s natural scenery. On December 7, we will be hiking a flat rail-trail portion of the Pequonnock River Trail. View the parking location HERE. Note: The trail is popular and gets busy on the weekends, so parking may be limited. We encourage you to arrive 15 minutes early. If there are no parking spots available, park in the large lot across the street (near the Starbucks on White Plains Road) and walk over to the meeting area.Use this form to sign the waiver for the 12/7 hike. Sign up for future updates HERE.



Chuck Winchell grew up in the Mill Hill area of Bridgeport in the 60’s. He has been involved with Groundwork Bridgeport since its inception in 1998, having served as a Board member and Chair. Chuck retired from the United Illuminating Company and enjoyed a second career with the State of Connecticut’s Department of Energy and Environmental Protection. In 1981 he hiked 1,000 miles of the Appalachian Trail and has been chipping away at the remaining 1,100 ever since. Besides hiking, Chuck’s other interests include swimming, biking, and weekly pinochle games.Chris Allen, a retired Agriscience teacher from Trumbull High School, specialized in the plant science portion of the program. He holds a degree in plant science from Penn State and has expertise in greenhouse production, hydroponics, and plant tissue culture. An avid hiker, Chris has explored nearly all local hiking trails, the Connecticut Appalachian Trail, and several peaks in New Hampshire's White Mountains.
